sec_questions: The first law of thermodynamics is nothing but the law of conservation of ________.
The first law of thermodynamics is based on the law of conservation of energy, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, but can be transferred from one form to another.
Which of the following statements is correct, in case of adiabatic expansion?

In the case of adiabatic expansion, the volume of the system increases \& hence work done is taken as positive but there is no heat exchange between the system \& the surroundings which means that \(\Delta Q=0\).

Therefore, From the first law of thermodynamics, we have

\(\begin{aligned} & 0=\Delta U+W \\ & \Delta U=-W \\ & \Delta U=\text { Negative }\end{aligned}\)

An isochoric process in the context of thermodynamics is a term used to describe a situation where the volume of a system remains constant.

According to the question, the work done by the system equals zero.

Work done is given by, \({\Delta W}={P} {\Delta V}\)

If the volume of the system remains constant then \(\Delta \mathrm{V}=0 \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{W}=\) 0

The process will be Isochoric.

In a thermodynamic process, when the pressure of a fixed mass of gas is changed, \(30 \mathrm{~J}\) heat is evolved and \(10 \mathrm{~J}\) work is done on it. If internal energy is \(100 \mathrm{~J}\), then the final internal energy is:

Given, 

Heat released by gas \((Q)=-30 \mathrm{~J}\), Work done on gas, \((\Delta \mathrm{W})\) \(=-10 \mathrm{~J}\), internal energy \(U_i=100 \mathrm{~J}\)

From the first law of thermodynamics, the final internal energy is

\(\begin{aligned} & \Delta U=Q-\Delta W \\ & \Rightarrow U_f-100=-30-(-10) \\ & \Rightarrow U_f=80 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)

A solid \(X\) is in thermal equilibrium with a solid \(Y\). Solid \(Y\) has the same temperature as solid \(Z\). If the three solids have different masses and compositions, which one of the following statements is correct?
\(X\) and \(Z\) have the same latent heat capacity
\(X\) and \(Y\) have the same heat capacity
Y may not necessarily be in thermal equilibrium with \(Z\)
There will be no net transfer of energy if \(X\) is placed in thermal contact with Z

\(X\) and \(Y\) are in thermal equilibrium. So, they both have the same temperature.

Given that \(Y\) has the same temperature as \(Z\). So \(Y\) and \(Z\) are in thermal equilibrium.

Therefore, \(X, Y\), and \(Z\) are in thermal equilibrium with each other. So, if \({X}\) is placed in thermal contact with \({Z}\), there will be no net transfer of energy.
Zeroth law of thermodynamics gives the concept of:

According to the Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics, when the thermodynamic systems A and \(B\) are separately in a thermal equilibrium with a third thermodynamic system \(C\), then the systems \(\mathrm{A}\) and \(\mathrm{B}\) are in thermal equilibrium with each other also.

If \(d Q\) is the heat given to thermodynamic system and \(d U\) is its change in internal energy and \(\mathrm{dW}\) is the work done on the system, then the first law of thermodynamics concludes that:

\(Q \rightarrow+v e\) (when the heat is transferred to the system)

\(Q \rightarrow\)-ve (when the heat is taken out of the system)

\(\mathrm{W} \rightarrow+\mathrm{ve}\) (when the work is done by the system)

\(\mathrm{W} \rightarrow\)-ve (when the work is done on the system)

From the first law of thermodynamics, \(\Rightarrow d Q=d U+d W\)

Since work is done on the system, therefore it will be negative

\(\Rightarrow d Q=d U=d W\)
In the isothermal process if the heat given to the system is \(100 \mathrm{~J}\), the change in internal energy and the work done of the system will be:

Given,

\(Q=100 \mathrm{~J}\)

In the isothermal process, the temperature remains constant during the process,

\(\Rightarrow \Delta T=0\)....(1)

The change in internal energy is given as,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta U=n C_v \Delta T \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta U=n C_v \times 0 \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{U}=0 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)

By the first law of thermodynamics,

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{W}+\Delta \mathrm{U} \\ & \Rightarrow 100=\mathrm{W}+0 \\ & \Rightarrow 100=\mathrm{W} \\ & \Rightarrow \mathrm{W}=100 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)
Which of the following is an intensive variable?

Intensive Property: These are the properties of the system which are independent of mass under consideration. For example: Pressure, Temperature, density, composition

Extensive Properties: The properties which depend on the mass of the system under consideration. For example: Internal Energy, Enthalpy, Mass, Volume, Entropy, weight.

From above it is clear that, the temperature is an intensive variable.

The melting point is the temperature at which a solid turns to a liquid

The melting point at which ice turns into liquid is \(0^{\circ} {C}\) or \(273 {~K}\).

Regelation is the phenomenon of ice melting under pressure and refreezing when the pressure is reduced.
The efficiency of a heat engine can never be:

A heat engine is a device which converts continuously heat energy to mechanical energy in a cyclic Process. The main parts of a heat engine are:

  • Source: It is a heat reservoir at a higher temperature  T1.
  • Sink: It is a reservoir at a lower temperature T2. 
  • Working Substance: Working substance is any gaseous or liquid substance that performs a mechanical work when heat supplied to it.
  • The diagram below shows the essential components of a heat engine.


Where,

HE = Heat Engine

TH = Temperature of Source / Hot reservoir

TL = Temperature of Sink / Cold Reservoir

Q1 = Heat absorbed from Source

Q2 = Heat rejected to Sink

The efficiency(η) of a heat engine is defined as:

\(\therefore \eta=\frac{W}{Q_{1}}=\frac{Q_{1}-Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}=1-\frac{Q_{2}}{Q_{1}}\)

Now, W = Q1  - Q2

The efficiency of the heat engine is always less than 1.  This is because in reality none of the engines can convert absorbed heat completely into work, as some of the heat will always be dissipated during the process. Also stated, according to the second Law no heat engine can have 100% efficiency
If the temperature of the source is increased, the efficiency of the Carnot engine:

The efficiency \((\eta)\) of the Carnot engine is given by:

\(n=1-\frac{T_C}{T_H}\)

Here if \(T_H\) increases, the value of \(T_C / T_H\) decreases, and hence the value of \(\left(1-T_d / T_H\right)\) increases. If the temperature of the source \(\left(T_H\right)\) is increased then the efficiency of the Carnot engine increases.
In which Thermodynamic process is there no flow of heat between the system and the surroundings?
In an adiabatic process, no heat flows between the system and surroundings.

An ideal gas heat engine operates in Carnot's cycle between \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C} \mathrm{It} \mathrm{absorbs}\) \(6 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\) at high temperature. The amount of heat converted into work is:

Given - \(T_1=227+273=500 \mathrm{~K}, T_2=127+273=400 \mathrm{~K}\), Heat absorbed by the engine is \(Q_1=6 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\)

The efficiency of heat engine is given by-

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \eta=\frac{W}{Q_1}=1-\frac{T_2}{T_1} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=1-\frac{400}{500} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=1-\frac{4}{5} \\ & \Rightarrow \frac{W}{6 \times 10^4}=\frac{1}{5} \\ & \Rightarrow W=\frac{6 \times 10^4}{5}=1.2 \times 10^4 \mathrm{~J}\end{aligned}\)
In thermodynamics_____________ is not a state variable.

Internal energy, pressure, density, and enthalpy are examples of state variables. Since they depend only on the final and initial states of the thermodynamical system.

Heat is a measure of the amount of energy present in a thermodynamical system. As the amount of energy changes the heat present in the system changes. Hence heat is the path variable.

What is the source temperature of the Carnot engine in K required to get \(70 \%\) efficiency?

Given sink temperature \(=27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
The heat given to an ideal gas in isothermal conditions is used to:
increase temperature and in doing external work

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a physical change in such a way that its temperature remains constant, then the change is known as an isothermal process.

As we know that the internal energy of the system is a function of temperature alone, so in the isothermal process, the change in internal energy is zero.

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}=0+\Delta \mathrm{W}=\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

Therefore, the heat given to an ideal gas in isothermal conditions is used to do external work.
110 joule of heat is added to a gaseous system whose internal energy is \(40 \mathrm{~J}\). Then the amount of external work done is:

Given that, \(\Delta Q=110 \mathrm{~J}, \Delta U=40 \mathrm{~J}\)

According to the first law of thermodynamics:

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{W}+\Delta \mathrm{U}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{U}=\Delta \mathrm{Q}-\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(40 \mathrm{~J}=110 \mathrm{~J}-\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=110-40=70 \mathrm{~J}\)
A Carnot engine whose sink is at 300 K has an efficiency of 40%. By how much should the temperature of the source be increased so as to increase its efficiency by 50% of original efficiency?

Temperature of \(\operatorname{sink} T_L=300 \mathrm{~K}\)

Original efficiency \(\eta=40 \%=0.4\)

Let the Initial temperature of the source be \(T_H\)

Using \(\eta=1-\frac{T_L}{T_H}\)

\(\therefore 0.4=1-\frac{300}{\mathrm{~T}_{\mathrm{H}}} \Longrightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=500 \mathrm{~K}\)

Now the efficiency of the engine is increased by \(50 \%\) of original efficiency,

\(\therefore\) New efficiency \(\eta^{\prime}=40 \%+20 \%=60 \%\)

\(\therefore \eta^{\prime}=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}}{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}}\)

OR \(0.6=1-\frac{300}{T_H^{\prime}}\)

\(\mathrm{OR} \frac{3 \mathrm{OO}}{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}}=0.4 \Rightarrow \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}=750 \mathrm{~K}\)

Increase in source temperature \(\Delta \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}^{\prime}-\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=750-500=250 \mathrm{~K}\)
If Q, E and W denote respectively the heat added, change in internal energy and the work done in a closed cycle process, then:

Internal energy depends only on the initial and final states of temperature and not on the path.

In a cyclic process, as initial and final states are the same, change in internal energy is zero \((\Delta E=0)\).

Hence \({E}\) is \(\Delta {U}\), the change in internal energy.
In thermodynamic processes which of the following statements is not true?
In an adiabatic process the system is insulated from the surroundings
In an isochoric process pressure remains constant
In an isothermal process the temperature remains constant.

An isochoric process is a thermodynamic process that occurs when the change in volume is zero.

Hence the statement 'In an isochoric process pressure remains constant is not true.
The internal energy change in a system that has absorbed 2 Kcal of heat and done 500 J of work is:

The First Law of Thermodynamics states that energy can be converted from one form to another with the interaction of heat, work and internal energy, but it cannot be created nor destroyed, under any circumstances. Mathematically, this is represented as

ΔH=ΔU+ΔnRT

where,

ΔH is the heat exchanged between a system and its surroundings,

ΔU is the total change in internal energy of a system,

ΔnRT is the work done by or on the system.

ΔH=2Kcal=8400J

W=500J

So,ΔU=8400−500=7900J
A thermodynamic system is taken through the cycle ABCD as shown in figure. Heat rejected by the gas during the cycle is:

Given: Cyclic process ABCDA



We know that,

In cyclic process

ΔU=0

So, from the first law of the thermodynamics,

ΔQ=ΔW= area under the PV curve.

ΔW=(2P−P)(3V−V)=2PV

∴ Heat rejected=2 PV

An ideal gas is taken through a cycle \(\mathrm{A} \rightarrow \mathrm{B} \rightarrow \mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) as shown in the figure. If the net heat supplied in the cycle is \(5 \mathrm{~J}\), then work done by the gas in the process \(\mathrm{C} \rightarrow \mathrm{A}\) is:

In the cyclic process : Δ=0

ΔQ=ΔW

ΔW=WA→B+WB→C+WC→A
WB→C=0 (volume remains constant)
WA→B=P(V2−V1)=10(2−1)=10J (pressure remains constant)
Therefore, 5=10+WC→A
⟹WC→A=−5J
Pick the one that is not a state variable of a thermodynamic system:

Heat is not a thermodynamic state variable as it is just a mode of energy transfer to the system.

Thermodynamic state variables are parameters which describe a system's equilibrium states. Example: temperature, pressure, volume, and internal energy.

A Carnot engine has an efficiency of \(\frac{1}{6}\). When the temperature of the sink is reduced by \(62^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), its efficiency is doubled. The temperatures of the source and the sink are, respectively:

An ideal gas heat engine operates in carnot cycle between \(227^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) and \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). It absorbs \(6 \times 10^4 \mathrm{cal}\) of heat at higher temperature. Amount of heat converted into work, is:

For a Carnot engine, efficiency e \(=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_2}{\mathrm{~T}_1}\)

\(=1-\frac{127+273}{227+273}\)

\(=1-\frac{400}{500}=\frac{1}{5}\)

Now, \(\mathrm{e}=\frac{\text { Work output }}{\text { Heat input }}=\frac{\mathrm{W}}{6 \times 10^4}\)

\(\mathrm{W}=\mathrm{e} \times 6 \times 10^4=\frac{1}{5} \times 6 \times 10^4\)

\(=1.2 \times 10^4 \mathrm{cal}\)
The second law of thermodynamics is concerned with the:

The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system can only increase over time. It can remain constant in ideal cases where the system is in a steady state (equilibrium) or undergoing a reversible process.

The second law of thermodynamics says that when energy changes from one form to another form, or matter moves freely, entropy (disorder) increases. Hence, it is concerned with the direction of flow of energy.
In gases of diatomic molecules, find the ratio of the two specific heat of gases \(\frac{C_p}{C_v}\) is :
A spherical black body with a radius of \(12 \mathrm{~cm}\) radiates 450 watt power at \(500 \mathrm{~K}\). If the radius were halved and the temperature doubled, the power radiated in watt would be:

Radius of the spherical black body, \(R_1=12 \mathrm{~cm}\)

Power radiated, \(\mathrm{P}_1=450\) watt

Temperature, \(t_1=500 \mathrm{~K}\).

New radius, \(R_2=6 \mathrm{~cm}\)

New temperature, \(t_2=2 t_1\)

New power \(=\mathrm{P}_2\)

Rate of power loss

\(P \propto R^2 T^4\)

\(\frac{P_1}{P_2}=\frac{R_1^2 T_1^4}{R_2^2 T_2^4}\)

\( =4 \times \frac{1}{16}\)

\(\frac{450}{r_2}=\frac{1}{4}\)

\(P_2=1800\) watt
The internal energy change for a system is \(+20 \mathrm{Cal}\) and the work done is \(-200 \mathrm{Cal}\). Find the heat exchanged between the system and the surrounding.

Given that:

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-200 \mathrm{Cal}\) and \(\Delta \mathrm{U}=+20 \mathrm{Cal}\)

According to the first law of Thermodynamics:

Heat exchanged \((\Delta Q)=\Delta W+\Delta U=-200+20=-180 \mathrm{Cal}\)
When the amount of work done is \(333 \mathrm{cal}\) and change in internal energy is \(167 \mathrm{cal}\), then the heat supplied is:

Given \(-\Delta W=333 \mathrm{cal}\) and \(\Delta U=167 \mathrm{cal}\)

From the first law of thermodynamics, we have

\(\begin{aligned} & \Rightarrow \Delta Q=\Delta U+\Delta W \\ & \Rightarrow \Delta Q=167+333=500 \mathrm{cal}\end{aligned}\)
If heat is supplied to an ideal gas in an isothermal process:
The internal energy of the gas will increase

For an ideal gas, Internal energy \(U=f(T)\) only

As the process is isothermal, so \(T\) will remain constant or \(\Delta T=0\)

\(\therefore \Delta U=0\)

From First Law of Thermodynamics

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

As Heat is Supplied to the system is +ve so, work will also be +ve. \((\Delta W=+v e)\)

So, we can say that the work is done by the gas.
The correct thermodynamic conditions for the spontaneous reaction at all temperatures is:
ΔH>0 and ΔS<0
ΔH<0 and ΔS>0
ΔH<0 and ΔS<0

ΔH<0 and ΔS>0

∵ ΔG=ΔH−TΔS

For reaction to be spontaneous, ΔG should be negative, this works if ΔH is negative and ΔS is positive.
\(400 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done on a gas to reduce its volume by compression adiabatically. What is the change in internal energy of the gas?

Given \(-\Delta W=400 \mathrm{~J}\)

For the adiabatic process,

\(\Delta \mathrm{Q}=0\)

As work is done on the gas, so

\(\Delta \mathrm{W}=-400 \mathrm{~J}\)

Change in internal energy,

\(\Delta U=\Delta Q-\Delta W=0-(-400)\)

\(\Delta U=-400 \mathrm{~J}\)
The change in internal energy of a 2 moles of a gas is \(-10 \mathrm{~J}\). Find the work done on the gas if the process is adiabatic.

Given - \(\Delta U=-10 \mathrm{~J}\)

When a thermodynamic system undergoes a physical change in such a way that its change in heat remains constant, then the change is known as an adiabatic.

In adiabatic process, \(\Delta {Q}=0\)

From the first law of thermodynamics:

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{Q}=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow 0=\Delta \mathrm{U}+\Delta \mathrm{W}\)

\(\Rightarrow \Delta \mathrm{W}=-(-10)=10 \mathrm{~J}\)
A device that converts heat energy into work in a cyclic process is:

A heat engine is a closed-cycle device that takes heat from a hot reservoir, does useful work and rejects the remaining heat to a cold reservoir. A device that converts heat energy into work in a cyclic process is a heat engine.
For the thermodynamic heat pump, heat flows from:

A heat pump is a device that maintains a system or a body at a temperature higher than the surrounding temperature.

In the heat pump, the heat is removed from the low-temperature body and is added to the high-temperature body.
A gas expands adiabatically at constant pressure such that its temperature \(T \propto \frac{1}{\sqrt{V}}\), the value of \(C_p / C_r\) of gas is:

Given, 

\(T \propto V^{\frac{-1}{2}}=T=k V^{\frac{-1}{2}}=k=T V^{\frac{1}{2}} \ldots\) (1)

For adiabatic process, \(\mathrm{PV}^{\mathrm{Y}}=\) constant or \(k=T^{Y-1} \ldots\) (2)

equating both the equations we get,

\(\mathrm{TV}^{\frac{1}{2}}=\mathrm{TV}^{\mathrm{Y}-1}\)

\(\mathrm{Y}-1=\frac{1}{2}\)

\(\mathrm{Y}=\frac{3}{2}\)
A black body is heated from \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) to \(127^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\). The ratio of their energies of radiations emitted will be:

We know that

\(\mathrm{E}=\sigma \mathrm{T}^4\)

Where \(\mathrm{E}\) is rate of emission of radiation of a body at temperature \(\mathrm{T}\).

\(\mathrm{E}_1=\sigma(27+273)^2\)

\(\mathrm{E}_2=\sigma(127+273)^2\)

\(\frac{\mathrm{E}_1}{\mathrm{E}_2}=\frac{(300)^4}{(400)^4}=\frac{81}{256}\)
The ratio of the relative rise in pressure for adiabatic compression to that for isothermal compression is :

For adiabatic case slope of \(\mathrm{PV}\) graph is given by \(\gamma \times(\frac{\mathrm{P}}{ \mathrm{V}})\) and for isothermal case it is given by \((\frac{\mathrm{P}}{\mathrm{V}})\).

Ratio of them will be \(\gamma\).

One gram of water on evaporation at atmospheric pressure forms \(1671 \mathrm{~cm}^3\) of steam. The heat of vaporisation at this pressure is \(540 \mathrm{cal} / \mathrm{gm}\). The increase in internal energy is:

\(\begin{gathered}\Delta Q=\Delta U+P \Delta V \\ m L=\Delta U+P \Delta V \\ \Delta U=m L-P \Delta V \\ m L=1 \times 540=540 \mathrm{cal}\end{gathered}\)

\(P \Delta V=1 \times 10^5(1671-1) \times 10^{-6}=167 \mathrm{~J}\)

\(=\frac{167}{4.2}=40 \mathrm{~cal}\).

\(\therefore \Delta U=540-40=500 \mathrm{cal}\)

3 moles of gas requires \(60 \mathrm{cal}\) of heat for \(5^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) rise in temperature at constant volume. Then heat required for 5 moles of the same gas under constant pressure for \(100^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) raise in temperature is:

At constant volume, \(\mathrm{W}={0}\)

So, \(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}\)

\(60=3 C_v \times 5\)

\(C_V=4\)

\(C_p=C_v+R\)

\(C_p=4+2=6\)

At constant pressure,

Q = nCpΔT

Q = 5×6×100

Q = 3000 cal
In an adiabatic change, the pressure P and temperature \(T\) of a monoatomic gas are related as \(P \propto T^c\) where c equals-

In adiabatic process, relation between P and T :

\(\mathrm{P}^{1-\gamma} \mathrm{T}^\gamma=\) constant

so P \(\alpha T ^\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}\)

\(\gamma=\frac{5}{3}\) for monatomic gas

and \(c=\frac{\gamma}{\gamma-1}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \text { so } \mathrm{c}=\frac{\frac{5}{3}}{\frac{5}{3}-1} \\ & \mathrm{C}=\frac{5}{2}\end{aligned}\)
A fixed amount of dry air at temperature of \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) is compressed to \((\frac{1}{ 9})^{\text {th }}\) of original volume. Its final temperature is \((\gamma=1.5)\)

In a thermodynamic process, pressure of a fixed mass of a gas is changed in such a manner that the gas releases \(20 \mathrm{~J}\) of heat and \(8 \mathrm{~J}\) of work is done on the gas. If initial internal energy of the gas was \(30 \mathrm{~J}\), what will be the final internal energy?
A quantity of heat ' \(Q\) ' is supplied to a mono-atomic ideal gas which expands at constant pressure. The fraction of heat that goes into work done by the gas is:

The heat \(\mathrm{Q}\) is converted into the internal energy and work. According to the first law of thermodynamics,

\(\mathrm{Q}=\mathrm{U}+\mathrm{W}\)

\(\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}=\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}+\mathrm{W}\)

The dfraction of heat converted to work is given as

\(\frac{\mathrm{W}}{\mathrm{Q}}=\frac{\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}-\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{v}} \Delta \mathrm{T}}{\mathrm{nC}_{\mathrm{p}} \Delta \mathrm{T}}=\frac{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}-\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{v}}}{\mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{p}}}=\frac{\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}-\frac{3}{2} \mathrm{R}}{\frac{5}{2} \mathrm{R}}=\frac{2}{5}\)

A given mass of a gas is compressed isothermally until its pressure is doubled. It is then allowed to expand adiabatically until its original volume is restored and its pressure is then found to be 0.75 of its initial pressure. The ratio of the specific heats of the gas is approximately:

let Initial value of volume,pressure and temperature of gas be \(V_0, P_0, T_0\)

In step one, gas is compressed isothermally, so temperature will be constant

After first step :

Pressure \(=2 \mathrm{P}_0 ;\) Temperature \(=\mathrm{T}_0\)

from \(P V=n R T\) Volume \(=\frac{V_0}{2}\);

In 2nd step, gas is allowd to expand adiabatically to restore its original volume

After 2nd step:

Pressure \(=0.75 \mathrm{P}_0\), Volume \(=\mathrm{V}_0\),

from the adiabatic process relation between \(\mathrm{P}\) and \(\mathrm{V}-\mathrm{PV}^\gamma=\) constant

\(P_1 V_1^\gamma=P_2 V_2^\gamma\)

\(\left(\frac{V_1}{V_2}\right)^\gamma=\frac{P_2}{P_1}\)

\(\begin{aligned} & \mathrm{V}_1=\frac{\mathrm{V}_0}{2}, \mathrm{P}_1=2 \mathrm{P}_0 \\ & \mathrm{~V}_2=\mathrm{V}_0 \text { and } \mathrm{P}_2=0.75 \mathrm{P}_0\end{aligned}\)

so \(\left(\frac{\frac{\mathrm{V}_0}{2}}{\mathrm{~V}_0}\right)^{\gamma}=\frac{0.75 \mathrm{P}_0}{2 \mathrm{P}_0}\)

\(\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^\gamma=\frac{3}{8}\)

on solving this:

\(\gamma=1.41\)
A heat engine operates between 2100 K and 700K. Its actual efficiency is 40%. What percentage of its maximum possible efficiency is this ?

Maximum possible efficiency of a heat engine \((\eta)=1-\frac{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{c}}}{\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{h}}}=1-\frac{700}{2100}=\frac{2}{3}\)

Given that the actual efficiency is 0.4.

Percentage of the maximum possible efficiency \(=\frac{0.4}{\frac{2}{3}} \times 100=\frac{6}{10} \times 100=60\)
A man of \(60 \mathrm{~kg}\) gains \(1000 \mathrm{Cal}\) of heat by eating 5 mangoes. His efficiency is \(56 \%\). To what weight he can jump by using this energy?

After eating 5 mangoes energy gain \(=1000 \mathrm{Cal}\)

Efficiency \(=5.6 \%\)

Energy can be utilized \(=\) Efficiency \(\times 5\)

\(=560\) Cal

\(=2352\) J

Now, \(\mathrm{mgh}=2352\)

\(\mathrm{h}=\frac{2352}{60 \times 9.8}=4\) m
The rate at which is energy is radiated by a black body at an absolute temperature is given by:

The Stefan-Boltzmann law for the emissive power gives the total energy emitted by a blackbody.

\(E_b=\sigma T^4\)

where \(E_b\) is the emissive power of a blackbody, \(T\) is absolute temperature, and ( \(\sigma=\) \(5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} / \mathrm{m}^2 / \mathrm{K}^4\) ) is the Stefan-Boltzmann constant.
Newton's Law of cooling is an approximate form of:
Newton's law cooling is a special case of Stefan-Boltzmann's law where the temperature difference of the body and the surrounding is very small.
The law of thermodynamics that hints at the fact that no heat engine can have efficiency equal to \(100 \%\) is the:
The second law suggests that no heat engine can convert 100% of its input heat energy (QH) into work (W).
Which of the following law of thermodynamics is responsible for heat transfer?

The transfer of heat is primarily governed by the laws of thermodynamics, and specifically, the second law of thermodynamics is most directly related to heat transfer. The second law of thermodynamics states that the total entropy of an isolated system will never decrease over time; it tends to increase or, at best, remain constant. In the context of heat transfer, it implies that heat will naturally flow from regions of higher temperature to regions of lower temperature, and not the other way around.
Heat does not spontaneously flow from a colder body to a hotter one. Which of the following thermodynamics law states this?

The concept of entropy as a physical attribute of a thermodynamic system is established by the second law of thermodynamics. Despite following the necessity of energy conservation as specified in the first law of thermodynamics, entropy predicts the direction of spontaneous processes and determines whether they are irreversible or impossible.
What is the value of the absolute thermodynamic temperature scale?
The temperature of an object on a scale with 0 as absolute zero is known as absolute temperature, also known as thermodynamic temperature. Kelvin and Rankine are absolute temperature scales.
Which of the following is chosen as the standard thermometric substance?
Smallest variation is observed among different gas thermometers.
The entropy of an isolated system can never ____.
The entropy of an isolated system always increases and remains constant only when the process is reversible.
Which of the following processes is reversible?

One type of reversible air compression and expansion is described by the isothermal process, where the heat of compression and expansion is removed or added to the system at the same rate as it is produced.

A Carnot engine having an efficiency of \(1 / 10\) as heat engine, is used as a refrigerator. If the work done on the system is \(10 \mathrm{~J}\), the amount of energy absorbed from the reservoir at lower temperature is:

When a system is taken from state '\(x\)' to state '\(y\)' then \(30 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of heat flows into the system and the system does \(10 \mathrm{~kJ}\) of work. When the system is returned from state '\(\mathrm{y}\)' to state '\(\mathrm{x}\)' along another path, then work done on the system is \(8 \mathrm{~kJ}\). What is the amount of heat liberated?

We know that:

First law of thermodynamics for a process is given by

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W\)

When the system is taken from state \({x}\) to state \({y}\) then:

\(\mathrm{Q}_{x-y}=+30 \mathrm{k} J, W_{x-y}=+10 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics,

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(+30 k J=d u_{x-y}+10 \mathrm{~kJ} \)

\( d u_{x-y}=30-10 \)

\( d u_{x-y}=20 \mathrm{k} J\)

Now,

When the system is taken from state \({y}\) to state \({x}\) then:

\(W_{y-x}=-8 \mathrm{~kJ} \text { and }\)

\(\mathrm{d} U_{y-\mathrm{x}}=-20 \mathrm{~kJ} [\because\left(U_{y}-U_{x}\right)=-\left(U_{x}-U_{y}\right)]\)

Then from first law of thermodynamics

\(\delta Q=d U+\delta W \)

\(Q_{y-x}=-20-8 \)

\(\therefore Q_{y \cdot x}=-28 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Here negative sign indicates that heat is being liberated.

A reversible Carnot engine works between the temperature of \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). Heat supplied to the engine by \(1000 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir is \(250 \mathrm{~kJ}\). Now the work obtained by this engine is supplied to the refrigerator which works between the temperature limits of \(270 \mathrm{~K}\) and \(300 \mathrm{~K}\). The COP of the refrigerator is \(50 \%\) of the COP of the reversible refrigerator then find out the heat rejected by the refrigerator (in \(\mathrm{kJ}\) ) at the reservoir which is at \(300 \mathrm{~K}\).

Given:

For engine

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=300 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=1000 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{Q}_{\mathrm{s}}=250 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

Now, The efficiency of the Carnot engine is given by:

\(\eta=1-\frac{T_{L}}{T_{H}}\)

Where \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=\) temperature of the low-temperature reservoir and \(\boldsymbol{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=\) temperature of the high-temperature reservoir.

\(=1-\frac{300}{1000}=0.7\)

Again, The efficiency of an engine is given by:

\(\eta=\frac{W_{n e t}}{Q_{\text {supplied }}} \)

Where \(\mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\) Net work done by the engine and \(\mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}=\) Heat supplied to the engine.

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=\eta \times \mathrm{Q}_{\text {supplied }}\)

\(=0.7 \times 250 \)

\(\therefore \mathrm{W}_{\text {net }}=176 \mathrm{k} \mathrm{J}\)

Now this work is supplied to the refrigerator,

For refrigerator,

\(\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{L}}=270 \mathrm{~K} \text { and } \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}}=300 \mathrm{~K}\)

COP of a reversible refrigerator is given by:

\(C O P=\frac{T_{L}}{T_{L}-T_{H}}\)

Where, \(T_{L}=\) Temperature of the evaporator and \(T_{H}=\) Temperature at which heat is rejected.

\(\therefore C O P=\frac{270}{300-270}=9\)

Now,

The actual COP is \(60 \%\) of the ideal COP

\(\therefore \text { COP }_{\text {actual }}=9 \times 0.5=4.5\)

Again,

\(C O P=\frac{\text { Desired Effect }}{\text { Work Input }} \)

\(\Rightarrow 4.5=\frac{\text { Desired } E f \text { fect }}{175 \mathrm{~kJ}} \)

\( \text { Desired effect }=4.5 \times 175 \)

\(=787.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

\(\) The heat rejected to the \(300 \mathrm{~K}\) reservoir by the refrigerator \(=787.6+176=962.6 \mathrm{~kJ}\)

\(T_1=500k,~T_2=1000k,~T_f=750k\)

\(m=2,~C_p=1\)

According to the question:

Heat lost by block \(1=\) Heat gained by block 2

\(\therefore m C_{p}\left(T_{1}-T_{f}\right)=m C_{p}\left(T_{f}-T_{2}\right) \)

\(\therefore T_{f}=\frac{T_{1}+T_{2}}{2}=750 K\)

Now,

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 1}+(\Delta s)_{\text {block } 2} \)

\(=m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+m C_{p} \ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right) \)

\(=m C_{p}\left(\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{1}}\right)+\ln \left(\frac{T_{f}}{T_{2}}\right)\right) \)

Put all given values in above equation:

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=2 \times 1 \times\left[\ln \left(\frac{750^{2}}{500 \times 1000}\right)\right] \)

\((\Delta s)_{\text {total }}=0.2355 ~{k J}/{K}\)

The weight of the diesel engine, compared to similar petrol engine is

The weight of the diesel engine is 2 to 3 times greater compared to similar petrol engine.

  • Diesel engines or (C.I.Engines) are heavier than petrol engines (S.I.Engines) because of the large compression ratio in the case of diesel engines. The reason for the large compression ratio being compression ignition i.e. in diesel engines, ignition takes place by the high temperature developed by the compression since there is no spark plug like in petrol or S.I.Engine.
  • Also, the flashpoint at which fuel gets ignited is more in the case of diesel engines so the compression ratio needs to be sufficient enough to produce that self-ignition temperature of the fuel for the combustion to take place.
  • Compression ratio (r): It is defined as the ratio of volume before compression to the volume after compression.

\(r=\frac{\left(V_{c}+V_{s}\right)}{V_{c}}\)

where \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{C}}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{\mathrm{S}}\) are clearance and swept volume respectively.

  • The value of the compression ratio for diesel engines lies between \(16: 1\) to \(22: 1\) whereas for the petrol engine it lies between \(6: 1\) to \(12: 1\).

\(\mathrm{P}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{P}_{2}=\) initial and final pressure

\(\mathrm{V}_{1}\) and \(\mathrm{V}_{2}=\) initial and final volume,

Increase in the size of the evaporator

• In a vapor compression refrigeration system, the sub-cooling of refrigerant in the condenser results in increase in the size of the evaporator.
  • Sub cooling is the process of cooling the liquid refrigerant below the condensing temperature for a given pressure.
  • The difference between the saturation temperature and the temperature of sub cooled liquid at that pressure is called Degree of sub cooling.

Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the following type of expansion device.

Domestic refrigerator working on vapour compression cycle uses the 'Capillary tube' of the expansion device.

  • The capillary tube is one of the most commonly used throttling devices in domestic refrigerators, deep freezers, water coolers, and air conditioners. Capillary tubes have very small internal diameters and very long lengths and they are coiled to several turns so that they would occupy less space (compact). They are easy to manufacture, cheap and compact.
  • When the refrigerant leaves the condenser and enters the capillary tube, its high pressure drops down suddenly due to the very small diameter of the capillary tube and the long length gives more friction head and drops pressure further.
  • The decrease in pressure leads to the cooling of the refrigerant and the low-temperature refrigerant can take the heat from the room.

To ease the flow of the refrigerant

Refrigeration system:

  • A refrigeration system contains a minimum of four key components i.e., compressor, condenser, expansion valve, and evaporator.
  • The purpose of the expansion device is to rapidly reduce the pressure of the refrigerant in the refrigeration cycle.
  • This allows the refrigerant to rapidly cool before entering the evaporator.
  • An expansion device is located closer to the evaporator in order to minimize heat gain.
  • The most common devices are capillary tubes, thermal expansion valves, electronic expansion valves.
